speaker: therapist
text: Hello, welcome back. How have you been since our first meeting? Any reflections or moments that stood out?

speaker: client
text: Hi. It's been... mixed. I felt a bit of relief after talking last week. But then, yesterday, I had another one of those moments. At work. It wasn't a snap, more of a collapse. I just went completely numb in a meeting. I've been thinking about that 'signal' idea, but I couldn't hear anything. Just static.

speaker: therapist
text: Thank you for sharing that. The numbness is just as important a signal as the anger. It's often a protective layer, a way the mind shuts down when emotions feel too dangerous or overwhelming. Can you describe the moment right before the numbness set in?

speaker: client
text: My manager was reviewing a project I'd done. He said it was 'adequate,' but then listed five or six things that could have been better. Everyone was just nodding. I felt my face get hot, my heart started pounding... and then it was like a switch flipped. The noise faded, and I just felt hollow. I don't even remember the rest of the meeting.

speaker: therapist
text: That's very clear. So first, there was a physiological reaction—heat, pounding heart. That's the emotion rising. Then, the numbness, the hollow feeling. It sounds like your system went into a kind of shutdown to protect you from what was coming up. What do you think that initial surge of emotion was, before the switch flipped?

speaker: client
text: (Sighs) I don't know. Embarrassment? Shame, definitely. Feeling exposed. Like I was being told, in front of everyone, that my best effort was just... mediocre.

speaker: therapist
text: That's a powerful, painful feeling. 'My best is mediocre.' I'd like to try something with that feeling, if you're willing. It's a technique we mentioned last time called a two-chair dialogue. It can help us understand these internal conflicts more clearly.

speaker: client
text: You mean the one with the two chairs? I'm nervous, but okay. What do I do?

speaker: therapist
text: We'll go slowly. I'll ask you to give a voice to two different parts of yourself that were in conflict in that meeting. The first part is the one that felt the shame, the exposure, the hurt. The second is the part that responded with numbness, that shut everything down to protect you. We'll let them speak to each other. Are you comfortable trying?

speaker: client
text: I think so. Yes.

speaker: therapist
text: Good. Let's start by focusing on that moment of hearing 'adequate.' I'd like you to sit in this chair and speak as the **Hurt Part**. The part that felt the shame. Give it a voice. What does it want to say?

speaker: client
text: (Moves to chair, takes a deep breath) It wants to say... 'This isn't fair. I worked so hard. I stayed late. And now everyone sees I'm not good enough. I'm humiliated. I want to disappear.'

speaker: therapist
text: Thank you. That's very clear. 'I want to disappear.' Now, I'd like you to physically move to this other chair. This is the **Protective Numb Part**. This is the part that made the hollow feeling, that shut down the noise. As this part, what is your job? Why did you step in when the Hurt Part said 'I want to disappear'?

speaker: client
text: (Moves to the other chair, posture becomes more rigid) My job is to keep you safe. That pain was too much. If you feel all of that, you'll fall apart. You won't be able to function. I made you disappear so you wouldn't have to feel the full force of it. I turned down the volume to zero.

speaker: therapist
text: Okay. Now, stay in that chair. I want the Hurt Part to hear that. The Numb Part says it was protecting you from falling apart. Now, go back to the first chair. You are the Hurt Part again. Having heard that, what do you say back to the Protector?

speaker: client
text: (Returns to first chair, voice softer) I... I know you're trying to help. But when you make me go numb, it's like I *do* disappear. I'm not there. And afterwards, I feel even worse. Empty and disconnected. It doesn't feel like safety. It feels like being erased.

speaker: therapist
text: That's a profound insight. 'It feels like being erased.' Now, go back to the Protector's chair. How do you respond to hearing that your protection feels like erasure?

speaker: client
text: (In protector chair) What else am I supposed to do? Let you drown in that shame? You can't handle it. It's too big. I've seen it before. It crushes you. At least when you're numb, you can still breathe. You can get through the day.

speaker: therapist
text: So the Protector sees the Hurt as fragile, unable to bear the weight of its own feelings. It's choosing between two bad options: crushing pain or empty numbness. Now, as yourself, the whole person observing this dialogue, what are you noticing?

speaker: client
text: (Returns to original seat, visibly emotional) I'm noticing... that they're both trying to help in their own broken way. The Hurt part just wants to be seen and validated, and the Protector thinks the only way to survive is to kill the feeling. But they're both *me*. And I'm stuck in the middle.

speaker: therapist
text: That is an incredibly important realization. They are both you, and both have a function. The Hurt part holds your genuine needs—for recognition, for competence, for your effort to be valued. The Protector is trying to manage an unbearable situation. The conflict isn't about getting rid of either one; it's about helping them work together differently.

speaker: client
text: How do they work together? They seem like complete opposites.

speaker: therapist
text: By asking the Protector to shift its job slightly. Instead of 'erase the feeling,' its job could become 'help me feel this safely and in manageable doses.' What if, in that meeting, instead of full shutdown, the Protector could have allowed you to feel a wave of hurt, while also whispering, 'I'm here, you're okay, breathe, we'll process this later'?

speaker: client
text: (Tears up) That sounds... compassionate. The protector right now feels more like a ruthless bodyguard. But a compassionate one... that would be different.

speaker: therapist
text: Exactly. We're aiming for an internal compassionate bodyguard. Let's try a quick exercise. Close your eyes if you're comfortable. Picture that Hurt part—the one feeling humiliated. Now, imagine the Protector part, but instead of a wall of numbness, imagine it as a steady, calm presence. What would that compassionate protector say to the hurt part right now?

speaker: client
text: (Eyes closed, pauses) It would say... 'I see how much that hurt. Your feelings are valid. You worked hard. We don't have to feel it all right this second. We can just acknowledge it, and we'll be okay.'

speaker: therapist
text: How does that feel internally, to hear that?

speaker: client
text: It feels... sad, but clean. The hurt is still there, but it's not chaotic. It's not threatening to destroy me. The numbness isn't there. It's just... a sad, understood feeling.

speaker: therapist
text: That's the beginning of emotion regulation. It's moving from being hijacked by the emotion or completely avoiding it, to being with it, acknowledging it, and soothing it. This is the core work. Does this connect back to what we talked about last week—the anger as a signal?

speaker: client
text: Yes. The anger was a signal I didn't understand, so I snapped. The shame here was a signal I was afraid of, so I went numb. They're both signals I didn't know how to process. The signal was 'your need to be valued feels threatened.'

speaker: therapist
text: Brilliant. You've connected it to an unmet need from attachment: the need for validation, to feel that your efforts are seen and valued. When that need feels threatened, the alarm system goes off—shame, anger. Our job is to hear the alarm, understand what it's protecting, and respond with care, not just react.

speaker: client
text: This feels huge. And exhausting. But in a good way. Like I've been digging in the dark and finally hit something solid.

speaker: therapist
text: It is huge. And it is work. For this week, I'd like you to practice this 'compassionate bodyguard' idea. When you feel a strong emotion or the beginnings of numbness, just pause. Ask internally: 'What is the signal? What need feels threatened?' Then, try to offer one sentence of that compassionate, steady presence to yourself. You don't have to fix it, just acknowledge it.

speaker: client
text: Okay. I can try that. 'I see you. We're okay.' Something like that.

speaker: therapist
text: Perfect. And we'll continue to build on this. This is the path out of the fog—not by fighting it, but by learning to be with yourself in a new, kinder way. How are you feeling as we end today?

speaker: client
text: Raw. But clear. And... cautiously hopeful. Like I have a tool now, however small, instead of just being at the mercy of these storms.

speaker: therapist
text: That's an excellent place to be. Hold onto that hope. I'll see you next week. Be gentle with yourself.
